newsitem.title: USA: Oklahoma City prosecutors end on graphic note.
newsitem.headline: Oklahoma City prosecutors end on graphic note.

text.p: Prosecutors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial rested their case on Wednesday after calling a survivor and a firefighter to drive home to jurors the horror of the worst attack on civilians in U.S. history.
"Your honour, on behalf of the United States, I'm pleased to announce that we rest," chief prosecutor Joseph Hartzler told federal Judge Richard Matsch shortly before midday.

The prosecution presented 137 witnesses in 18 days, weaving a web of circumstantial evidence to tie defendant Timothy McVeigh to the April 19, 1995 blast that took 168 lives at the Alfred P. Murrah federal building.

The prosecution's final witnesses included the head of the Federal Employees Credit Union, who described how seven women she was holding a meeting with disappeared when the bomb went off and a firefighter who described how people were mutilated when the building collapsed.
Chief defence attorney Steven Jones said he would present his first witness on Thursday. He told reporters his case may last "possibly less than two weeks."
Prosecutors allege McVeigh, 29, bombed the federal building to avenge the 80 Branch Davidian cult members killed in a confrontation with federal agents at Waco, Texas in 1993.
McVeigh, a decorated Gulf War veteran, pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and conspiracy. He could face the death penalty if convicted.
After the jury was dismissed for the day, Jones filed a motion to dismiss the charges against McVeigh on the grounds the prosecution had failed to prove its case.
Matsch denied the motion, which is routinely filed by the defence in criminal cases, but reserved judgment on defence motions to delete parts of the indictment against McVeigh.

Jones said prosecutors failed to prove allegations in the indictment that McVeigh bought 2,000 pounds (907 kg) of ammonium nitrate or that the bomb was built at a state park in Kansas. Ammonium nitrate was a key component of the bomb, the prosecution says.
The prosecution kept some of its most graphic testimony for last, clearly trying to impress on jurors' minds the carnage and destruction in the federal building.

Florence Rogers, chief executive of the Federal Employees Credit Union on the third floor of the Murrah building, described in a low voice how seven women employees she was meeting with in her office were blown away by the blast.
"When I was able to stand up, all of the girls in my office had totally disappeared, with the six floors from above us on top of them. I never saw them again," Rogers said.
Relatives of bombing victims sobbed as Rogers read out the names of 18 credit union employees killed in the blast.
Mike Shannon, special operations chief of the Oklahoma City Fire Department, described how people were squeezed when the building collapsed, creating a hazard for rescuers.

"Everything was crushed into a very small space. That created like a grape effect, squeezing grapes. Body fluids were dripping through and it would just drip onto your gear as you were crawling through, onto your helmet ... so there was a problem with disease," he testified.

Shannon said when he first entered the building after the blast a woman grabbed him. "She put her nose to my nose and chastised me about the children of the second floor, telling me to get up there...," he said. Nineteen children were killed, most of them in the second-floor day care centre.
McVeigh sat impassively through most of the session.
The final prosecution witness was Fred Jordan, the Oklahoma state medical examiner, who described the grim task of identifying the bodies.

Prosecution witnesses have testified that McVeigh talked about bombing the federal building and shopped for bomb materials. A witness identified McVeigh as the man who rented the Ryder truck used in the bombing and an FBI scientist said he found traces of explosives on McVeigh's clothes.
But there were gaps in the prosecution case. No one placed McVeigh in Oklahoma City on the day of the bombing and his fingerprints were not found on key evidence.
